article.title: Quasi-local charges and the Generalized Gibbs Ensemble in the Lieb-Liniger model

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key observation from Figure 1 regarding the expansion of ε₀(λ) using different charge bases?
choices: All three charge bases provide equally good approximations to ε₀(λ).
The expansion with Hermite charges converges much faster than the other two.
The transformed cosine and Chebyshev charges yield rapidly converging expansions for ε₀(λ).
Increasing the number of charges always leads to a worse approximation of ε₀(λ).

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main takeaway from Figure 2 regarding the reconstruction of the mode occupation density?
choices: The GGE&EX method always provides a better reconstruction than the GGE&EV method.
Increasing the number of charges in the GGE does not improve the reconstruction accuracy.
Both GGE&EV and GGE&EX methods fail to accurately reproduce the mode occupation density.
The GGE&EV method with a sufficient number of charges yields an almost perfect reconstruction of the mode occupation density.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of Figure 3 in the context of comparing GGE&EV and GGE&EX methods?
choices: To show that both methods yield identical generalized temperatures regardless of the truncation.
To demonstrate that increasing the cutoff in the integral (88) has no impact on the temperature differences.
To illustrate that the convergence of GGE&EV temperatures to their GGE&EX counterparts might be limited by the truncation and the finite integration cutoff.
To argue that GGE&EV method is fundamentally flawed and should not be used for determining generalized temperatures.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4 demonstrate regarding the reconstruction of the density-density correlation function using transformed cosine charges?
choices: Increasing the number of charges has no effect on the accuracy of the reconstruction.
Truncated GGEs with a sufficient number of transformed cosine charges can accurately capture the density-density correlations.
The GGE approach fails to reproduce the qualitative features of the density-density correlation function.
Only a GGE containing an infinite number of charges can accurately describe the density-density correlations.

multiple_choice_question.text: Comparing Figures 4 and 5, what can be inferred about the effectiveness of transformed cosine charges vs. Hermite function charges in reconstructing the density-density correlation function?
choices: Transformed cosine charges outperform Hermite function charges in capturing the density-density correlations.
Both charge bases provide equally good reconstructions of the correlation function.
Hermite function charges are more efficient as they require fewer terms for a comparable accuracy.
The choice of charge basis has no impact on the accuracy of reconstructing the correlation function.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of Figure 6 in the context of using quasi-local charges to describe the interaction quench?
choices: It demonstrates that truncated GGEs based on quasi-local charges can capture the dynamic structure factor with reasonable accuracy.
The figure highlights the failure of quasi-local charges to accurately reproduce the DSF, even with a large number of terms.
It emphasizes that the DSF is not a suitable observable for assessing the validity of a truncated GGE description.
The figure showcases the superiority of ultra-local charges over quasi-local charges in describing the interaction quench dynamics.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 7, which set of charges provides the most accurate reconstruction of ρp(λ) for the trap release quench?
choices: Quasi-local Hermite charges
Quasi-local cosine charges
Ultra-local charges
All three charge bases perform equally well
